title: Rings and Fields - Ring Definitions and Properties

questions.prompt: A ring (R, +, ·) must satisfy all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Distributive laws: a(b+c) = ab + ac and (a+b)c = ac + bc
questions.explanation: A ring requires (R,+) to be an abelian group, multiplication to be associative and closed, and distributive laws. A multiplicative identity is not required (though rings with identity are common). Rings with multiplicative identity are called "rings with unity."

questions.prompt: In any ring R, the additive identity 0 satisfies:
questions.explanation: In any ring, 0·a = 0 for all a ∈ R. This follows from 0·a = (0+0)·a = 0·a + 0·a, which implies 0·a = 0.

questions.prompt: A commutative ring is one where:
questions.explanation: A ring is commutative if ab = ba for all a, b ∈ R. Addition is always commutative in any ring (since (R,+) is an abelian group).

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a ring?
options: (N, +, ·) where N is the natural numbers
questions.explanation: N is not a ring because (N,+) is not a group - natural numbers lack additive inverses. All the others are rings.

questions.prompt: A unit in a ring R with identity is an element that:
questions.explanation: A unit (or invertible element) is an element a ∈ R such that there exists b ∈ R with ab = ba = 1.

title: Rings and Fields - Integral Domains and Fields

questions.prompt: An integral domain is a commutative ring with unity that has:
questions.explanation: An integral domain is a commutative ring with 1 ≠ 0 and no zero divisors (if ab = 0, then a = 0 or b = 0).

questions.prompt: In the ring Z₁₂, which element is a zero divisor?
questions.explanation: In Z₁₂, 3 is a zero divisor because 3·4 = 12 ≡ 0 (mod 12), and neither 3 nor 4 is zero. Elements 1, 5, 11 are units.

questions.prompt: A field is a commutative ring with unity where:
options: Every nonzero element is a unit
questions.explanation: A field is a commutative ring with 1 ≠ 0 where every nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a field?
options: Z under standard addition and multiplication
Z₆ under addition and multiplication modulo 6
Q under standard addition and multiplication
questions.explanation: Q is a field: every nonzero rational has a multiplicative inverse. Z is not (e.g., 2 has no inverse), Z₆ is not (3 is a zero divisor), 2Z doesn't even have unity.

questions.prompt: For which values of n is Zₙ a field?
questions.explanation: Zₙ is a field if and only if n is prime. When n is prime, every nonzero element is coprime to n and thus has a multiplicative inverse.

title: Rings and Fields - Ideals and Polynomial Rings

questions.prompt: An ideal I of a ring R is a subring such that:
options: rI ⊆ I and Ir ⊆ I for all r ∈ R
questions.explanation: An ideal I is a subring closed under multiplication by any element from R: if a ∈ I and r ∈ R, then ra ∈ I and ar ∈ I.

questions.prompt: In the ring Z, which of the following is an ideal?
questions.explanation: For any n, nZ is an ideal of Z. If a ∈ nZ and r ∈ Z, then ra ∈ nZ. In fact, every ideal of Z has this form.

questions.prompt: A principal ideal is an ideal that:
options: Can be generated by a single element
questions.explanation: A principal ideal is one of the form ⟨a⟩ = {ra : r ∈ R} for some a ∈ R. In Z, all ideals are principal.

questions.prompt: In the polynomial ring R[x] where R is a ring, elements are:
questions.explanation: R[x] is the ring of polynomials with coefficients in R, under usual polynomial addition and multiplication.

questions.prompt: If F is a field, then F[x] is:
options: An integral domain but not a field
questions.explanation: If F is a field, F[x] is an integral domain (no zero divisors) but not a field, since polynomials of degree ≥ 1 don't have multiplicative inverses in F[x].
